body: Were other devices maybe announcing changes at this time? Apart from the retry on failure (with backoff expected) we also trigger immediate pulling when a new index update is received or a connection comes/goes... (If so that should result in a "burst" of these non-backoffed rounds, but not as many as you seem to describe.)

To clarify the situation a bit, this hyena server of which I've given the those logs is a kind of "hub" server.  I do never modify the files on this server, it is used as a central point for other syncthings to connect to.  Therefore, this server does not have a filewatcher enabled, and the rescan time has been configured to be more then 30 days, so in practice it is only re-scanned each restart of syncthing.

This particular folder is sharing with 2 other devices.   One is online (home nas) and the other is offline (laptop).
The other online server (home nas) is also a "hub", no local modifications and no fswatcher.  it is sharing to other devices at home.
I've looked at that other "hub" (home nas) and altough I cannot find the logfile, if I go into the webif and look at the log there, the files are also retried immediately without respecting any backoff.

As the files in question are stored in version control, I've been able to figure out what has changed on the device that is offline (laptop)  The directory git/projectA has been renamed/files moved to git/categoryA/projectA, and a new symbolic link file with the name git/projectA has been added that points to git/categoryA/projectA.  I can only asume that I've shut down my laptop while the files were not yet fully transferred... (I cannot acces the laptop at this moment)

What system is the laptop? The specific error you are getting is a typical symptom of case-only renames (renaming foo to Foo). I didn't check, but that might also cause the eternal pulling, as the error triggers a scan, something (not sure what that could be) in the scan retriggers a pull, etc.

Regardless of the underlying problem here, it might be reasonable to throttle triggered pulls to e.g. 1/s.

All systems that share this folder are unix based.  The home nas is freebsd, all others are debians.  The laptop is debian testing.

Both hubs: nas (freebsd) and server (debian) are experiencing the issue.

Another strange thing I just noticed, on both hubs, clicking on the "recent changes" button in the ui gives the following result.  This keeps on modifying itself, every time the same with a newer timestamp.  Again, I do not use those working directories directly, so I do not modify these files.  Note that I've paused the connection between all machines, so these folders do NOT have any peers to talk to...

Seems like this is more suited for the forum until we get to the bottom of this?
We are currently debugging in IRC and while not at the bottom, there's already one quite bad issue uncovered (yeii, symlinks again). I'll update later.

There's multiple issues here, I don't yet fully understand how the entire cycle comes to pass. I believe the following log excerpt covers at least one full cycle:

https://gist.github.com/imsodin/6e6bc1202c4832be00021bf1bdbdc0ec

The full log as reported by @Peter4825 is this:

https://spider.pfoe.be/fulllog2.txt

For context `/rest/db/file` output for an affected file:  
https://pastebin.com/h0ha6QCK  
https://pastebin.com/2WUkGLfC  

The two IDs with the huge version vectors are the "hubs" (nas and server).

The cycle works even when no devices are connected and goes like this:
On syncing, tries to delete a file behind symlink, is suprised at what it sees there, thus schedules a scan. that scan goes havoc by first seeing something behind that link and thus marking as existing in db, then later realizing it's behind a symlink, thus deleting it in db. as these are two operations, scan schedules syncing. rinse and repeat.

There's one clear and simple issue: We shouldn't even look at stuff behind symlinks when handling a deletion on syncing (even if we don't follow through with deletion here, which is good).

Then there's the scanner doing really weird/bad stuff:
```
Oct 17 23:11:10 hyena syncthing[15805]: [2WOFS] 2019/10/17 23:11:10.010124 folder_sendrecv.go:1687: DEBUG: sendreceive/workfolder@0xc000410000 scheduling scan after pulling for git/projectA/smsgw/info-failover.txt
[...]

Oct 17 23:11:10 hyena syncthing[15805]: [2WOFS] 2019/10/17 23:11:10.010696 walk.go:364: DEBUG: rescan: File{Name:"git/projectA/smsgw/info-failover.txt", Sequence:7714878, Permissions:00, ModTime:2019-10-11 09:24:58.242041033 +0200 CEST, Version:{[{Y6PO6KN 2} {2WOFSJ6 1486921}]}, Length:0, Deleted:true, Invalid:false, LocalFlags:0x0, NoPermissions:false, BlockSize:0, Blocks:[]} 1570778698 -rw-r--r--
Oct 17 23:11:10 hyena syncthing[15805]: [2WOFS] 2019/10/17 23:11:10.010728 walk.go:367: DEBUG: to hash: git/projectA/smsgw/info-failover.txt File{Name:"git/projectA/smsgw/info-failover.txt", Sequence:0, Permissions:0644, ModTime:2019-10-11 09:24:58.242041033 +0200 CEST, Version:{[{Y6PO6KN 2} {2WOFSJ6 1486921}]}, Length:502, Deleted:false, Invalid:false, LocalFlags:0x0, NoPermissions:false, BlockSize:131072, Blocks:[]}

```
Looks like it's resolving the symlink to be scanned ahead of actually walking.

Fixing the puller side of things is straight-forward (testing not so much). The scanner I yet need to figure out. Right now I am calling it a day.

There was an issue with the logs - the scanner is also following symlinks, probably it doesn't handle being given a path behind a symlink as root path for walking as opposed to not descend into symlinks.

How do you (@calmh @AudriusButkevicius) judge the priority on this? I am bit short on time at the moment. I could probably come up with a fix fairly quickly (famous last words before being much shorter on time), but this definitely needs good tests - which I cannot do before next week.
I think rush is not enormous. There are some corner cases required to end up in this situation.

issue.body:
### Purpose

When deleting files/dirs we do not check for symlinks in the path. In #6090 this resulted in a scan being scheduled, because before deleting it checks the db and does not find the same as it sees on disk behind the symlink.

### Testing

Check that neither a db update nor a scan goes through when trying to delete a file behind a symlink.
